    Discovery of Potent and Centrally Active 6-Substituted 5-Fluoro-1,3-dihydro-oxazine β-Secretase (BACE1) Inhibitors via Active Conformation Stabilization

    • Kenji Nakahara
      Kenji Nakahara
      Discovery Research Laboratory for Core Therapeutic Areas, Shionogi Pharmaceutical Research Center, 1-1 Futaba-cho 3-chome, Toyonaka, Osaka 561-0825, Japan

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    β-Secretase (BACE1) has an essential role in the production of amyloid β peptides that accumulate in patients with Alzheimer’s disease (AD). Thus, inhibition of BACE1 is considered to be a disease-modifying approach for the treatment of AD. Our hit-to-lead efforts led to a cellular potent 1,3-dihydro-oxazine 6, which however inhibited hERG and showed high P-gp efflux. The close analogue of 5-fluoro-oxazine 8 reduced P-gp efflux; further introduction of electron withdrawing groups at the 6-position improved potency and also mitigated P-gp efflux and hERG inhibition. Changing to a pyrazine followed by optimization of substituents on both the oxazine and the pyrazine culminated in 24 with robust Aβ reduction in vivo at low doses as well as reduced CYP2D6 inhibition. On the basis of the X-ray analysis and the QM calculation of given dihydro-oxazines, we reasoned that the substituents at the 6-position as well as the 5-fluorine on the oxazine would stabilize a bioactive conformation to increase potency.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, accounting for approximately 50% to 60% of all dementia cases.(1) In 2015, 46.8 million people worldwide were suffering from dementia.(2) According to a survey in the United States, AD is the sixth leading cause of death, with 11% of people aged 65 and older suffering from AD. Total costs in 2016 for patients with AD and other dementias were estimated at $236 billion in the U.S., of which the national care service is expected to cover 68%. AD ultimately leads to death within 3–9 years after diagnosis. More significantly, there is a great impact on the quality of life for patients as well as their caregivers. Indeed, a study indicated that 40% of family caregivers suffer from depression, and as a result, 72% of them experienced relief when the dementia patients died.(1) Unfortunately, none of the medications available today for AD slows or stops the disease progression, which points to a great unmet medical need for disease-modifying therapy for AD.
    The accumulation of β-amyloid plaques, which are composed of amyloid β (Aβ) peptides of 38–43 amino acids and an abnormal form of hyper-phosphorylated tau proteins, are the histopathological hallmarks of AD.(1,3) Therefore, targeting inhibition of Aβ peptide production is considered to be a key strategy for disease-modification of AD.(4) The β-site APP cleaving enzyme 1 (BACE1), also known as β-secretase or memapsin 2, is a rate-limiting enzyme in Aβ peptide production.(5) BACE1, an aspartic protease, cleaves the amyloid precursor protein (APP) to generate a soluble N-terminal domain of APP (sAPPβ) followed by cleavage of the membrane-bound C-terminus of C99 by γ-secretase to generate the Aβ peptides. Among all isoforms of Aβ (total Aβ), the Aβ42 consisting of 42 amino acids is the most toxic form, as it readily aggregates to generate toxic oligomers which ultimately result in deposition of amyloid plaques.(6) Although γ-secretase is a potential target for therapeutics to reduce the Aβ peptide, inhibition of the processing of other substrates, such as Notch, raises concerns about safety in clinical use, and its modulation suffers from lack of efficacy.(7) Thus, reducing Aβ by inhibiting BACE1 is considered to be an attractive approach to disease modification.
    Genetic evidence also supports the importance of BACE1 inhibition in AD. The Swedish mutations in APP of K670N and M671L, close to the cleavage site in BACE1, cause familial AD by increasing the processing and production of total Aβ.(6) The increased production of APP as observed in people with Down syndrome also results in early onset AD due to the rapid accumulation of Aβ.(1) Furthermore, an APP variant of A673T has been found to be protective against AD, as it reduces the APP processing by BACE1 resulting in approximately 40% inhibition of Aβ production.(8) Such evidence provides further support for BACE1 as a promising AD target.
    Since the discovery of BACE1 in 1999, a number of pharmaceutical companies and academic institutions have focused on exploring potent and brain penetrant BACE1 inhibitors.(9−11) Because of the challenging nature of the target, the large size of the catalytic site, attention was initially directed at peptidomimetic inhibitors such as statine- and hydroxyethylamine-based analogues derived from its transition state. Although the peptidomimetics were found to be potent in biochemical or binding assays, their low cellular potency as well as high P-gp efflux resulted in poor central efficacy in relevant preclinical models.(9) After the identification of amidine-based small molecule inhibitors,(12) many research groups have focused on the optimization of this class of BACE inhibitors.(11) These efforts have overcome the issues observed with the peptidomimetics and led to the development of clinical BACE1 inhibitors, such as LY-2811376,(13) LY-2886721,(14) verubecestat (1, MK-8931),(15) elenbecestat (2, E-2609),(16) RG-7129,(17) AZD-3839,(18) lanabecestat (AZ-3293),(19a) CNP520,(19b) and JNJ-54861911 (Chart 1).(20) Some of the clinical inhibitors achieved robust Aβ reduction in humans, while compounds such as LY-2811376, LY-2886721, and AZD-3839 failed due to off-target related toxicity,(13,14) indicating the need for other chemotypes to ensure successful development of BACE1 inhibitors for the market.
    In contrast to fragment-based drug discovery programs pursued by other companies,(13,15) our early research efforts began with a successful high throughput screen campaign of our corporate compounds utilizing a cellular Aβ production assay. This delivered the hit compound 3,(21) which was contingently the same as that of Roche’s;(22) their efforts culminated in compound 4, with significant CSF Aβ reduction in rat at a low dose. Our subsequent hit-to-lead SAR effort yielded initial leads 5 and 6 (Chart 2). Because these leads had distinct profiles in terms of potency, P-gp recognition, and brain penetration, our strategy to identify BACE1 clinical candidates was to optimize the two leads in parallel; work on the thiazine 5 will be reported elsewhere. Dihydro-oxazine 6 demonstrated good in vitro potency while displaying suboptimal hERG selectivity and high P-gp efflux, which resulted in low brain penetration and no significant efficacy in our mouse model. Lowering pKa has been proven to be an effective approach to reduce both hERG inhibitory activity and P-gp efflux.(23) In another paper, we describe how we adopted this strategy to address these issues observed in 6 by inserting an olefin bond and following this with further optimization. This successfully reduced both the pKa and P-gp efflux, leading to oxazine 7, which displayed robust Aβ reduction in both mouse and dog at low doses.(24) Herein, we describe an alternative approach to mitigate the drawbacks of 6 by substituting the dehydro-oxazine headgroup with electron withdrawing groups followed by optimization of the tail group. This ultimately led to compounds 21 and 24 that showed robust Aβ reduction in vivo at low doses with reduced hERG and CYP2D6 inhibition.

    Results and Discussion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Exploration at the 6-Position of Dihydro-oxazine 8 Leading to 13

    Dihydro-oxazine 6 exhibited IC50 values of 118 nM in the biochemical assay and 3.7 nM in the cellular assay. The ability of 6 to reduce total Aβ levels in the brain was examined with wild-type mouse using po dosing at 10 mg/kg, where no significant Aβ reduction (15%) was observed at 6 h with a brain concentration of 29 ng/mL and a brain-to-plasma (B/P) ratio of 0.22. The poor efficacy and brain penetration were rationalized by its high P-gp efflux ratio of 20, which we postulated could be avoided by lowering the high basicity of the amino-dihydro-oxazine (pKa = 9.8). Another drawback of 6 was a high hERG inhibitory activity of 66% at 3 μM in an automated patch-clamp assay.
    During the course of our research, the Roche group reported that they had successfully lowered the pKa of 5-fluorinated oxazine 8(22b,25) to 8.1 as well as having increased its biochemical potency by 2-fold relative to 6 (Table 1). Importantly, the reduced pKa observed for 8 was associated with a mitigated P-gp efflux ratio of 4.0. Although 8 was still a P-gp substrate and showed a comparable hERG potency relative to 6, we considered 8 as a good template for further exploration. According to analysis using our proprietary BACE1 inhibitors, the lower limit of pKa for retaining cellular activity was 6.5.(24) Therefore, we sought to further decrease the basicity of 8 by introducing electron withdrawing groups at the 6-position on the dihydro-oxazine as shown in Table 1. Prior to the investigation, we explored a small set of substituents at the 5-position of 8. Consistent with Roche’s SAR, the compound with the opposite stereochemistry (10) exhibited pronounced reduction in potency.(22b) Because the fluorine at the 5-position showed good van der Waals interaction with Tyr132,(22b) a small substituent such as a methyl group was also expected to improve potency. Although 9 was less active than the corresponding F-analogue 8, a comparable potency was unexpectedly observed for 11 regardless of its opposite configuration at the 5-position to 9.
    Table 1. Exploration of the Head Group
    a

    Values represent the mean values of at least two determinations. Biochemical homogeneous time-resolved fluorescence (HTRF)-based assay. The IC50 value for the reference compound (CAS 797035-11-1) was 22.6 nM.

    b

    Efflux ratio measured in LLC-PK1 cells transfected with human MDR1.

    c

    Percent inhibition at 3 μM measured in CHO cells transfected with hERG channels using an automated patch clamp system.

    d

    pKa determined by capillary electrophoresis.

    We then pursued electron withdrawing groups at the 6-position in 8. As outlined in Table 1, introduction of the fluoromethyl group (13) imparted a 5-fold increase in activity, and a reduced pKa of 7.3 translated into a lower P-gp efflux and hERG inhibition. The corresponding diastereomer at the 6-position (12) caused a 10-fold decrease in activity, while the P-gp efflux and hERG activity were slightly mitigated, probably due to the reduction in the pKa by 0.2 unit. Encouraged by the improved profile observed for 13, we incorporated an alternative of the fluorine such as methoxy, which led to compounds 14 and 15. Unfortunately, these changes were accompanied by a moderate loss of biochemical potency as well as increased P-gp recognition. The increased P-gp efflux can be rationalized by the concomitant penalty of the higher basicity and the increased hydrogen bonding potential by the methoxy group relative to 13.
    Taken together, compound 13 with a low pKa of 7.3 achieved an optimal balance of potency, P-gp efflux, and hERG inhibition. Like 13, the improved values of P-gp efflux and hERG inhibition were observed in 12, with the lowest pKa value in Table 1, although its potency was reduced. However, with the other compounds having pKa values of 7.6 or higher, the lower pKa values (lower basicity) did not necessarily translate into reduced P-gp efflux and hERG inhibition. For example, compounds 10 and 15 with the same pKa value of 7.6 strongly inhibited hERG relative to the other compounds with higher pKa values (higher basicity). In addition, a significant difference in P-gp efflux was observed between 10 and 15 despite their having the same pKa value. Matched pair analysis of 5-fluoro-oxazines 8 and 10 indicated that 10 possessed higher hERG inhibitory activity than the more basic 8. These results imply that subtle structural modification might be a mitigation strategy for hERG and P-gp efflux for basic compounds like those shown in Table 1 with higher pKa values at the physiological pH (7.4), because such basic compounds are largely ionized at the physiological pH (e.g., 80% of compounds with a pKa of 8.0 are ionized at pH 7.4).
    To assess the pharmacokinetic (PK) profiles including brain penetration for the representative compounds in Table 1 of 6, 13, and 14, we utilized our screening rat PK studies using a cassette dosing method (Table 2). Prior to the investigation, the metabolic stabilities in rat microsomes for these compounds were determined to be in an acceptable range. The compounds were dosed intravenously (iv) at 0.5 mg/kg and orally (po) at 1 mg/kg. The brain concentration was measured at the 0.5 h time point in the iv study. As expected, compound 13, with an improved P-gp efflux relative to 6 and 14, achieved an increased B/P ratio of 0.62 as compared to 6 and 14 (B/P = 0.29 and 0.17, respectively). Moreover, a favorable PK profile was demonstrated in 13, with a low total clearance (CL) of 5.3 mL/min/kg and a high oral bioavailability (F) of 73%, resulting in a decent maximal plasma concentration (Cmax) of 101 ng/mL at 1 mg/kg. In parallel with the PK study, the cellular IC50 of 13 was determined to be 0.58 nM. Although compound 13 was demonstrated to be potent and brain penetrable, its hERG inhibitory activity was still in a suboptimal range (55% inhibition at 3 μM).
    Table 2. Pharmacokinetic Properties of Key Compounds for Sprague–Dawley Rats
        rat, iv, 0.5 mg/kg, n = 2arat, po, 1 mg/kg, n = 2b
    compdRLM (%)cfu,sdP-gp EReCL (mL/min/kg)fVdss (L/kg)gB/PhAUC (ng·h/mL)iCmax (ng/mL)jF (%)k
    61040.4120376.10.293283273
    13970.273.05.34.50.62239010173
    14780.416.3414.40.171662940
    201070.331.48.33.51.68857544
    21101ND1.49.35.41.96605835
    22100ND0.796.75.41.49926439
    24105ND1.8116.92.26305043
    a

    Dosed as a solution of test compounds in N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMA)/propylene glycol (PG) = 1/1.

    b

    Dosed as a suspension of test compounds in 0.5% methylcellulose (MC, 400 cP).

    c

    Percent remaining in rat liver microsomes after 30 min incubation.

    d

    Fraction unbound in rat serum. ND = not determined; the fu,s values for 21, 22, and 24 were not determined due to their instability in rat plasma.

    e

    Efflux ratio measured in LLC-PK1 cells transfected with human MDR1.

    f

    Total clearance.

    g

    Volume of distribution at steady state.

    h

    Total brain-to-plasma ratio.

    i

    Plasma area under the curve.

    j

    Maximal plasma concentration.

    k

    Oral bioavailability.

    Optimization of the Tail Group of 13

    To mitigate the hERG inhibition observed in 13, we explored a number of amide analogues as shown in Table 3. Incorporation of substituents at the ortho-position of the amide carbonyl, such as chloro (16), increased P-gp recognition while reducing hERG inhibitory activity. The fluoropyridine 17 reduced hERG potential and improved P-gp efflux, although the modification was associated with decreased potency. Replacement of the pyridine with a pyrazine generated compound 18 with a mitigated P-gp efflux and hERG potential. However, these improvements came at the price of decreased microsomal stability in human and increased CYP2D6 inhibition. In an effort to reduce such liabilities, we focused on exploring an alternative to the methoxy group in 18. While the difluoromethyl 19 increased metabolic stability in human microsomes, it lacked potency and still inhibited CYP2D6 with an IC50 value of less than 1 μM. Incorporation of a fluorine on the methoxy led to 20, which had an improved potency relative to 19 while retaining favorable values of P-gp efflux and hERG inhibition but also strong CYP2D6 inhibition.
    Table 3. Optimization of the Tail Group
    a

    Values represent the mean values of at least two determinations.

    b

    Biochemical homogeneous time-resolved fluorescence (HTRF)-based assay. The IC50 value for the reference compound (CAS 797035-11-1) was 22.6 nM.

    c

    IC50 determined by measuring the levels of secreted Aβ40 in human APP-transfected human neuroblastoma (SH-SY5Y) cells via an HTRF-based assay. The IC50 value for the reference compound (CAS 797035-11-1) was 25.9 nM.

    d

    Efflux ratio measured in LLC-PK1 cells transfected with human MDR1.

    e

    Percent inhibition at 3 μM measured in CHO cells transfected with hERG channels using an automated patch clamp system.

    f

    Percent remaining in human (HLM) and rat (RLM) liver microsomes after 30 min.

    g

    CYP2D6 inhibition measured with 5 μM dextromethorphan in human microsomes.

    Because 20 achieved a reduced P-gp efflux compared to 13, it was evaluated in a PK study with rat. As shown in Table 2, 20 demonstrated an improved B/P ratio of 1.6 as well as retaining favorable PK profiles such as a low CL and moderate to high Cmax and F values. Encouraged by the profile for 20, we considered additional analogues to address the CYP2D6 inhibition.

    Revisiting the 6-Position Leading to Compounds 21 and 24

    Reducing basicity and/or lipophilicity is one of the most commonly adopted strategies for mitigating CYP2D6 inhibition.(26) Here, we explored compounds with variation at the 6-position on the dihydro-oxazine (Table 4). To reduce the basicity in 20, we introduced a difluoroethyl at the 6-position, leading to 21 with a pKa reduced by 0.9 unit. Indeed, 21 displayed decreased CYP2D6 inhibitory activity (IC50 = 5.1 μM) while retaining potency and P-gp efflux relative to 20. Because incorporation of the difluoroethyl group was associated with an increased log D by 1.4 units over 20, lipophilicity was unlikely to be a critical factor for CYP2D6 inhibition. Because the modification also affected structural bulkiness around the region, we synthesized fluorocyclopropyl 22, which retained a similar level of pKa and had more bulkiness than 20. Interestingly, without reduction of the pKa, compound 22 achieved CYP2D6 inhibition comparable to the difluoroethyl analogue 21, indicating that the steric effect at the 6-position seems to be critical for mitigating inhibition of CYP2D6. In parallel with our efforts, the study reported by Brodney and co-workers at Pfizer utilizing the X-ray structure of dihydro-thiazines bound to CYP2D6 suggested the existence of a limited space around the 6-position, as the helix I in CYP2D6 is close to this space.(11f) Consistent with their result, addition of substituents to 20 at the 6-position, as in 21 and 22, resulted in diminished inhibition of CYP2D6.
    Table 4. Optimization of 1,3-Dihydro-oxazines at the 6-Position
    a

    Values represent the mean values of at least two determinations.

    b

    Biochemical homogeneous time-resolved fluorescence (HTRF)-based assay. The IC50 value for the reference compound (CAS 797035-11-1) was 22.6 nM.

    c

    IC50 determined by measuring the levels of secreted Aβ40 in human APP-transfected human neuroblastoma (SH-SY5Y) cells via an HTRF-based assay. The IC50 value for the reference compound (CAS 797035-11-1) was 25.9 nM.

    d

    Efflux ratio measured in LLC-PK1 cells transfected with human MDR1.

    e

    Percent inhibition at 3 μM measured in CHO cells transfected with hERG channels using an automated patch clamp system.

    f

    Percent remaining in rat (RLM) and human (HLM) liver microsomes after 30 min.

    g

    CYP2D6 inhibition measured with 5 μM dextromethorphan in human microsomes.

    h

    pKa determined by capillary electrophoresis.

    i

    log D determined in 1-octanol/phosphate buffer at pH 7.4.

    Having identified the key factor for reducing the CYP2D6 liability, we focused our attention on optimizing the substituents at the 6-position via steric modulation. Of the small set explored, a larger substituent than those in 21 and 22, such as the cyclopropyldifluoromethyl group (data not shown), decreased cellular potency by ∼10-fold while expanding the steric bulk of fluoromethyl 20 to the 1-fluoroethyl analogues 23 and 24 led to retention of cellular potency. Interestingly, the stereochemistry significantly affected inhibition of CYP2D6; (S)-1-fluoroethyl 23 exhibited a CYP2D6 IC50 value of below 1 μM, while the corresponding (R)-compound 24 showed an improvement of the CYP2D6 inhibition over that of 20, with a slightly improved cellular potency as well and a retained P-gp efflux ratio relative to the other compounds listed in Table 4. Regarding the other profiles of the stereoisomers 23 and 24, these two compounds had similar profiles for metabolic stability and P-gp efflux, while 24 was slightly more potent against hERG with a 32% inhibition at 3 μM.
    As for the cellular Aβ IC50 values included in Tables 3 and 4, a correlation between cellular and biochemical IC50 values was observed, indicating that the Aβ reduction observed in cells resulted from inhibition of BACE1 and not from the other enzyme responsible for the production of Aβ, γ-secretase; note here that our cellular assay did not directly measure sAPPβ, a product of BACE1 cleavage. Like other amidine-based BACE inhibitors, our compounds were more potent in the cellular than the biochemical assays. It was reasoned that basic inhibitors, such as the compounds in Table 3 and 4, could accumulate in the acidic endosome, where BACE1 resides and colocalizes with APP in cells, resulting in the more potent profile in cells.(11h) In addition, the good permeability observed for this series (e.g., passive apparent permeability coefficients in LLC-PK1 cells for 21, 22, and 24 were 20.9, 13.2, and 19.8 × 10–6 cm/s, respectively) may also affect the superior cellular potency.
    Compounds 21, 22, and 24 were tested against other aspartyl proteases cathepsin D (CatD) and BACE2. CatD is a well-known “anti-target” to be avoided.(9,15a) The development of a clinical BACE1 inhibitor LY2811376 was terminated after a three-month rat toxicology study, in which CatD related toxicities such as retinal and neuronal degeneration were observed.(11i) BACE2, a close homologue of BACE1, is ubiquitously expressed in the peripheral tissues as well as the brain.(27a) BACE2 is involved in the regulation of β cell mass(27b) and the processing of the pigment cell-specific melanocyte protein (PMEL).(27c) Although 21, 22, and 24 showed limited selectivity over BACE2 (IC50 = 44.1, 72.3, and 29.9 nM, respectively), no significant inhibition was observed in CatD for the compounds (IC50 = >100 μM).
    Pharmacokinetic profiles were obtained for compounds 21, 22, and 24 with reduced CYP2D6 inhibitory activity. As shown in Table 2, these compounds showed favorable and comparable PK profiles over 20, although the fu,s values were not determined due to instability in rat plasma. Similar to the PK profile of 20, the good metabolic stabilities and P-gp efflux ratios of these three compounds led to high exposure levels in the plasma and acceptable brain penetration.

    Cocrystal Structure of 21 Bound to BACE1

    The X-ray structure of compound 21 bound to a close form of human BACE1 was determined at a resolution of 2.2 Å (Figure 1). Consistent with the cocrystal structures of other amidine-based BACE1 inhibitors,(7a,11h,15a,22b,24) the amino-oxazine moiety has key interactions with the BACE1 catalytic dyad of Asp32 and Asp228, the fluorophenyl is oriented in a pseudoaxial conformation to occupy the S1 pocket, and the pyrazine ring fills the S3 pockets, where the linker amide NH between the two aryl rings engages in a hydrogen-bonding interaction with the carbonyl of Gly230. The fluoromethoxy on the pyrazine fills the S3 subpocket, and the fluorine on the fluorophenyl is projected toward Tyr71 in the flap region. The 6-difluoromethyl and 5-fluorine on the oxazine do not seem to engage in any interactions with BACE1, although these substituents contributed to an increase in potency.

    Conformational Analysis

    We found that the incorporation of the (5R)-fluorine (8) followed by the 6-fluoromethyl (13) had a profound impact not only on BACE1 potency but also on P-gp efflux. As discussed above, because no clear interactions were observed around these substituents in the cocrystal structure of 21 bound to BACE1, the increase in potency was considered to be caused in an entropy-driven manner, such as stabilizing active conformation or decreasing desolvation cost. Indeed, Hilpert and co-workers at Roche disclosed the X-ray structure of 10, the corresponding diastereomer of 8 with significantly reduced activity relative to 8; there was a vague electron density on the methylene at the 6-position, indicating that the (5S)-fluorine in 10 could destabilize the desired active pseudoaxial conformation. As with the 5-fluorine, the Roche group also demonstrated the importance of the stereochemistry at the 6-position for stabilizing the active conformation by their analysis of the CF3-oxazine 4 and its diastereomer at the 6-position. Given their finding and the analysis of our X-ray structure, we postulated that the improved potency could be attributed to stabilizing the active conformation. To test this hypothesis, we calculated the energy difference (ΔE) between the pseudoaxial and pseudoequatorial conformations of 6, 8, 10, 12, and 13 using quantum mechanical (QM) calculations. As shown in Figure 2, in support of our hypothesis, there was a strong correlation between the ΔEs and the BACE1 IC50 values (R2 = 0.88).
    Figure 3 provides an explanation of the results observed in the QM calculations. The nonsubstituted 6 prefers to adopt the pseudoaxial (active) conformation (ΔE = −1.11 kcal/mol). In the pseudoaxial conformation of 8 (R1A = F), the C–F bond is antiperiplanar to the C–H bond (R2B = H), which allows the favorable σC–H–σ*C–F interaction and is favored by 2.14 kcal/mol relative to 6 (ΔE = −3.25 kcal/mol).(28) In contrast, the pseudoaxial conformer in 10 (R1B = F) disrupts the interaction, while the pseudoequatorial (inactive) retains it, explaining why 10 exhibits a conformational preference for the inactive form, resulting in a significant decrease in potency (ΔE = +1.57 kcal/mol). The active conformation can be stabilized further when the fluoromethyl is incorporated in R2A (13) due to the 1,3-diaxal interactions between the methyl and the fluoromethyl groups in the inactive conformation (ΔE = −4.39 kcal/mol). Compound 12 prefers to adopt the inactive conformation in order to minimize the repulsive 1,3-diaxal interactions of the fluoromethyl with the fluorophenyl in the active conformation (ΔE = +0.27 kcal/mol).

    PK/PD Studies of 21 and 24

    Given the improved cellular potency, 2D6 inhibition, and PK profiles, compounds 21 and 24 were subjected to mouse PK/PD study. Prior to this, the metabolic stabilities in mouse of 21 and 24 were determined to be 89% and 102% (% remaining after 30 min incubation), respectively, and were comparable to those in rat. Male ICR mice were orally given compound 21 at a dose of 3 mg/kg, and plasma and brain levels at 2, 4, and 6 h time points were measured along with total Aβ levels in the brain (Figure 4A and Table 5). Compound 21 significantly reduced the total Aβ levels by 79% at the maximum total brain concentrations (Cb) of 1027 ng/mL. The unbound drug level in the brain (Cb,u) was determined to be 20 ng/mL (43 nM),(29) which clearly exceeded the cellular IC50 value of 1.9 nM. Because 21 achieved high exposure in mouse following oral administration at 3 mg/kg, it was given at a lower dose of 1 mg/kg. As shown in Figure 4B and Table 5, 21 demonstrated 58% reduction of total Aβ levels 4 h after dosing relative to vehicle-treated mice, where the maximum Cb was 296 ng/mL (Cb,u = 5.6 ng/mL; 12 nM). Compound 21 exhibited Cb,u/Cp,u values (unbound brain-to-plasma ratio) of greater than 1, as shown in Table 5 (the mean value for 21 at all the time points was 1.4). Although the reason is unclear, the use of rat fraction unbound ratio in the brain (fu,b) as a surrogate for mouse(29) and experimental error margins of measuring fu,b and fu,s may affect the result. Compound 24 was then evaluated using the mouse PD model at 1 and 3 mg/kg. As shown in Figure 4C and Table 5, 24 demonstrated robust and sustained reduction of Aβ levels in the brain over 6 h at 3 mg/kg. A maximal Aβ reduction of 66% was achieved at the 4 h time point, and it still reduced total Aβ by 64% at 6 h, where the maximum Cb value was 380 ng/mL (Cb,u = 11 ng/mL; 24 nM). Regarding the dose at 1 mg/kg (Figure 4D and Table 5), the maximal Aβ reduction was 44% with a maximum Cb of 143 ng/mL (Cb,u = 4.0 ng/mL; 9.2 nM).
    Table 5. Total Aβ Reduction, Plasma and Brain Concentrations, and Brain Penetration of 21 and 24 in Male ICR Micea
    compdfu,s/fu,bbdose (mg)time (h)Cp (ng/mL)cCb (ng/mL)dCb,ueB/PfCb,u/Cp,ugAβ reduction (%)

    240.065/0.02832203 ± 30380 ± 5810.61.90.8159 ± 1.2

       658.3 ± 5.7109 ± 5.73.051.90.8135 ± 5.6
    a

    Dosed as a solution of test compounds in 20% hydroxylpropyl-β-cyclodextrin (HPBCD).

    b

    fu,s = fraction unbound in mouse serum. fu,b = fraction unbound in rat brain (the rat fu,b values were used for the calculations).

    c

    Total plasma concentration.

    d

    Total brain concentration.

    e

    Unbound brain concentration (Cb,u = Cb × fu,b).

    f

    Total brain-to-plasma ratio.

    g

    Unbound brain-to-plasma ratio (Kp,uu). Cp,u = Cp × fu,s.

    The promising compound 24 was evaluated using our dog PD model(30) following the determination of metabolic stability in dog microsomes (99% remaining after 30 min) and fraction unbound ratio in dog serum (fu,s = 0.038). In the dog PD study, Aβ42 peptides in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) were measured at increasing doses of 0.16, 0.31, and 0.63 mg/kg for 49 h (Figure 5). CSF Aβ42 was maximally reduced by 75% after 25 h at 0.63 mg with plasma and CSF levels of 86 and 3.3 ng/mL, respectively; the inhibitory activity for Aβ42 was maintained even after 49 h with an Aβ reduction of 65%. At lower doses of 0.16 and 0.31 mg/kg, 24 exhibited maximum Aβ reductions of 45% and 64% at 8 h after dosing and sustained Aβ levels of 43% and 42%, respectively, after 25 h. The drug level in CSF (CCSF) at 0.16 mg/kg (25 h) was 0.77 ng/mL (1.7 nM), which was more or less the same level as the cellular IC50 of 1.1 nM. The good Cb,u/Cp,u values in mouse (Kp,uu; the mean value for 24 at all the time points in Table 5 was 0.84) translated into the CSF-to-unbound plasma ratio in dog (CCSF/Cp,u = 0.92; Kp,uu,CSF) at the 25 h time point. On the basis of the dose response data, the EC50 value, the plasma concentration that could reduce CSF Aβ42 by 50% was calculated to be 32 ng/mL (73 nM; EC50,u = 2.8 nM).

    Chemistry

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The synthesis of methyl-substituted oxazines 9 and 11 (Scheme 1) started with (R)-tert-butylsulfinylimine 25, readily available from the corresponding ketone.(31) Methyl propionate was transformed to the titanium enolate, which reacted with the imine 25 to afford the adduct 26 as an inseparable 6:1 diastereomeric mixture. Reduction of the ester in 26 led to the corresponding alcohol, and subsequent cleavage of the chiral auxiliary under acidic conditions gave the amino alcohol 27. Treatment with benzoyl isothiocyanate (BzNCS) formed the thiourea 28, and then we used 1-(3-(dimethylamino)propyl)-3-ethylcarbodiimide hydrochloride (EDC·HCl) to selectively activate the thiourea in the presence of the alcohol to obtain oxazine 29 in a diastereomeric ratio of 5:1. Further Boc protection of 29 allowed us to isolate 30 and 31 as single isomers by column chromatography. Deprotection of the two different protective groups was achieved via a two-step procedure, which was followed by nitration to give 32 and 33. The amidine moiety was reprotected with di-Boc followed by reduction of the nitro group to afford anilines 34 and 35. Finally, condensation with 5-cyanopicolinic acid followed by Boc-deprotection furnished the oxazines 9 and 11. The stereochemistry of compound 11 was verified by single crystal X-ray analysis based on the 4-bromobenzoyl protected 11 (see Supporting Information).
    As shown in Scheme 2, synthesis of oxazine 12 was achieved through a modified route to Scheme 1. We began with the fluorine-containing aldehyde 36,(22b) which was subjected to Wittig reaction to afford the homologated compound 37. Dihydroxylation of the terminal olefin gave the diol 38 in a stereoselective manner. Conversion of 38 to thiourea 39 was achieved over a two-step sequence, followed by cyclization to form the oxazine heterocycle yielding 40. Treatment with N,N-diethylaminosulfur trifluoride (DAST) gave the corresponding fluorine derivative 41. The relative configuration of 40 was assigned based on NOE analysis (see Supporting Information). From 41 to the target compound 12, we followed the synthetic route shown in Scheme 1.
    Oxazines 13–15 were prepared using a different strategy from 12 via a stereoselective iodocylization reaction (Scheme 3). Oxazine 14 was synthesized starting from addition of the lithium enolate of 2-methoxyacetate to the sulfinylimine 25, which gave an inseparable mixture of diastereomers with 44 as the major isomer. The ester group was reduced to the aldehyde 45 followed by homologation to afford 46. The dimethoxybenzyl (DMB) urea 48 was accessible via cleavage of the chiral auxiliary and subsequent conversion of the resulting amine to the urea. The corresponding fluorine analogue 47, a key intermediate for oxazines 13 and 15, was obtained according to the same procedure as that for 48. Intramolecular iodocyclization of 47 and 48 proceeded with excellent stereocontrol at the 6-position, leading to oxazines 49 and 50. The iodines in 49 and 50 were easily converted to hydroxyl groups by treatment with silver trifluoroacetate to form 51 and 52. Fluorination with DAST followed by deprotection of the DMB groups under acidic conditions afforded 56 and 57. Compound 58, an intermediate for 15, was obtained via methylation of the hydroxyl group in 51. The intermediates 56–58 were converted to the oxazines 13–15 in a manner similar to that in Scheme 2. The stereochemistry of 13 and 14 was verified by single crystal X-ray crystallography based on the 4-bromobenzoyl protected 13 and 14, respectively (see Supporting Information).
    The tail derivatives 16–20 were prepared from the common intermediate 59 (Scheme 4). The carboxylic acids used for synthesis of 19 and 20 were prepared according to known procedures.(32) A modified synthesis method for 5-(fluoromethoxy)pyrazine-2-carboxylic acid is described in the Supporting Information. Amide formation and subsequent Boc-deprotection with formic acid afforded the oxazines 16–20.
    Synthesis of oxazines 23 and 24 (Scheme 5) was initiated with ester 62,(22b) which led to 63 over two steps using the procedures described in Scheme 3. DIBAL reduction of the ester in 63 followed by Wittig reaction afforded 65 as an inseparable mixture of two regioisomers (E:Z = 2:3). The stereoselective iodocyclization established in Scheme 3 was applied to the internal olefin in 65 to give 66 and 67 from Z and E isomers of 65, respectively. Fluorines were introduced into 68 and 69 via the alcohol intermediates in a two-step protocol. Oxazines 23 and 24 were synthesized in a similar fashion to that described in the previous schemes. The absolute configurations in 23 were confirmed by single crystal X-ray analysis based on an analogue of 68 (see Supporting Information).
    As shown in Schemes 6 and 7, the synthesis of oxazines 21 and 22 was conducted via a similar reaction sequence as described in the previous schemes except for how substituents were introduced at the 6-position. The starting material 62 was converted to the Boc-protected ester 72 followed by treatment with DIBAL to afford aldehyde 73. Reformatsky reaction of 73 with ethyl 2-bromo-2,2-difluoroacetate proceeded well, and then the resulting alcohol spontaneously reacted with the Boc group to generate the cyclic carbamate 74. Reduction of the ester to the corresponding alcohol followed by iodination by Appel reaction led to 75. Radical reduction of the iodo functionality and subsequent Boc protection of the carbamate yielded 76, which was converted to amino alcohol 77 via hydrolysis of the cyclic carbamate. After deprotection of the Boc group, we conducted the synthesis of oxazine 21 via a common synthetic route. The absolute and relative configurations of 21 were confirmed by the X-ray structure bound to BACE1.
    For the synthesis of 22 (Scheme 7), we started with the cyclic carbamate 75, which was allowed to react with zinc, affording the exo-olefin 82 via reductive elimination of iodine and fluorine atoms. Conversion to amino alcohol followed by Boc-deprotection afforded 83. Construction of the oxazine scaffold through treatment with BzNCS and subsequent EDC·HCl gave 85, which was protected with Boc and then subjected to diazomethane generated in situ to form the corresponding cyclopropane derivative 86. According to the general sequence, we prepared the oxazine 22 from the intermediate 86.

    Conclusions

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    This paper has described the successful development of 6-substituted 5-fluoro dihydro-oxazine BACE1 inhibitors starting from the cellularly potent leads 6 and 8. Incorporation of an electron-withdrawing fluoromethyl group at the 6-position reduced the hERG potential and P-gp efflux but increased potency, resulting in 13. Conformational analysis revealed that stabilizing a pseudoaxial active conformation by introducing substituents at the 5- and 6-positions could contribute to increasing the potency observed in 13 as well as 8. Replacement of the cyanopyridine with methoxypyrazine was effective for further mitigating both hERG inhibitory activity and P-gp efflux but associated with increased CYP2D6 inhibition and low metabolic stability. The metabolic liability was addressed by incorporating a fluoromethoxy group, while increased steric bulkiness at the 6-position successfully reduced the CYP2D6 inhibition, leading to 21 and 24. These two compounds showed favorable PK profiles in rat including decent B/P ratios and achieved robust Aβ reduction in mouse at below 3 mg/kg. Finally, compound 24 exhibited significant and sustained Aβ reduction at a dose of no more than 0.16 mg/kg in dog, leading to a plasma Aβ42 EC50 value of 32 ng/mL.

    Experimental Section

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    General Chemistry

    All commercial reagents and solvents were used as received unless otherwise noted. Thin layer chromatography (TLC) analysis was performed using Merck silica gel 60 F254 thin layer plates (250 μm in thickness). Flash column chromatography was carried out on an automated purification system using Yamazen or Fuji Silysia prepacked silica gel columns. 1H NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker Advance 400 MHz. Spectral data are reported as follows: chemical shift (as ppm referenced to tetramethylsilane), multiplicity (s = singlet, d = doublet, dd = double doublets, dt = double triplet, t = triplet, q = quartet, m = multiplet, br = broad peak), coupling constant, and integration value. Analytical LC/MS was performed on a Shimadzu Shim-pack XR-ODS (C18, 2.2 μm, 3.0 mm × 50 mm, a linear gradient from 10% to 100% B over 3 min and then 100% B for 1 min (A = H2O + 0.1% formic acid, B = MeCN + 0.1% formic acid), flow rate 1.6 mL/min) using a Shimadzu UFLC system equipped with an LCMS-2020 mass spectrometer, LC-20AD binary gradient module, SPD-M20A photodiode array detector (detection at 254 nm), and SIL-20AC sample manager. The purity of all compounds used in the bioassays was determined by this method to be >95%. High resolution mass spectra were recorded with a Thermo Fisher Scientific LTQ Orbitrap using electrospray positive ionization.

    General Procedure for Condensation with Carboxylic Acids and Deprotection of Boc Group

    A mixture of aniline (1.0 equiv), carboxylic acid (1.05–1.20 equiv), HATU (1.2 equiv), and N,N-diisopropylethylamine (2.0 equiv) in DMF or DCM was stirred at room temperature. The mixture was quenched with water. The aqueous layer was separated and extracted with EtOAc. The combined organic layers were washed with brine, dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and evaporated. The residue was purified by flash column chromatography to give Boc-protected amide. To a flask containing this compound was added an excess amount of formic acid (>100 equiv) at room temperature. The mixture was stirred at room temperature and quenched with saturated aqueous NaHCO3 solution. The aqueous layer was separated and extracted with EtOAc. The combined organic layers were washed with brine, dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and evaporated. The crude product was purified by flash column chromatography and/or recrystallization to give the target compound.

    N-(3-((4R,5R,6R)-2-Amino-5-fluoro-6-(fluoromethyl)-4-methyl-5,6-dihydro-4H-1,3-oxazin-4-yl)-4-fluorophenyl)-5-cyanopicolinamide (13)

    Compound 13 (2.75 g, 92% over 2 steps) was prepared from 59 (3.50 g, 7.39 mmol) following the general procedure. White solid. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 1.50 (s, 3H), 3.84–4.01 (m, 1H), 4.53 (dt, J = 48.7, 8.7 Hz, 1H), 4.74 (dd, J = 45.6, 10.0 Hz, 1H), 5.13 (d, J = 48.3 Hz, 1H), 5.87 (s, 2H), 7.22 (t, J = 10.2 Hz, 1H), 7.81–7.88 (m, 1H), 7.89–7.96 (m, 1H), 8.28 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 8.59 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 9.21 (s, 1H), 10.95 (s, 1H). HRMS-ESI (m/z): [M + H]+ calcd for C19H17F3N5O2 404.1329, found 404.1322.

    N-(3-((4R,5R,6R)-2-Amino-5-fluoro-6-(methoxymethyl)-4-methyl-5,6-dihydro-4H-1,3-oxazin-4-yl)-4-fluorophenyl)-5-cyanopicolinamide (15)

    N-(3-((4R,5R,6R)-2-Amino-5-fluoro-6-(fluoromethyl)-4-methyl-5,6-dihydro-4H-1,3-oxazin-4-yl)-4-fluorophenyl)-5-fluoropicolinamide (17)

    N-(3-((4R,5R,6R)-2-Amino-5-fluoro-6-(fluoromethyl)-4-methyl-5,6-dihydro-4H-1,3-oxazin-4-yl)-4-fluorophenyl)-5-(fluoromethoxy)pyrazine-2-carboxamide (20)

    Compound 20 (25.0 mg, 59% over 2 steps) was prepared from 59 (47.0 mg, 0.099 mmol) following the general procedure.
